Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

> You can argue that you should refactor... well unless someone has a
> _real_ good reason to spend time refactoring something that works
> perfectly, he would rather do other things that don't currently work.
>

The reason I spend time refactoring is to keep the code as simple and expressive as
possible so that new features can be added economically.  The "if it works, don't
touch it" maxim leads ultimately to code rot, in my experience.  If I let it fester
too long, it will become increasing difficult to make new things work.

Anyway, that's my real good reason...

Mike
